title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
group_by
So far, we have applied vectorized operations to data.frames:

select: Keep and drop columns
mutate: Create new columns
filter: Keep and drop rows


For each of these, we have operated on the whole data set
Often, we instead want to operate on chunks of the data at a time

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
group_by
Recall our penguins:

penguins



# A tibble: 344 √ó 3
  species bill_length_mm body_mass_g
  <fct>            <dbl>       <int>
1 Adelie            39.1        3750
2 Adelie            39.5        3800
3 Adelie            40.3        3250
# ‚Ñπ 341 more rows



Heaviest penguin:

penguins |> slice_max(body_mass_g)



# A tibble: 1 √ó 3
  species bill_length_mm body_mass_g
  <fct>            <dbl>       <int>
1 Gentoo            49.2        6300

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
group_by
How can we get the heaviest penguin of each species?

Conceptually:

Split the data into three groups
Apply slice_max to each group separately
Combine the three rows back together



Sometimes called the split-apply-combine paradigm

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
group_by
Implemented using the group_by adverb

Doesn‚Äôt do anything on its own
Changes the behavior of other functions



penguins |> group_by(species) |> slice_max(body_mass_g)

# A tibble: 3 √ó 8
# Groups:   species [3]
  species   island bill_length_mm bill_depth_mm flipper_length_mm body_mass_g
  <fct>     <fct>           <dbl>         <dbl>             <int>       <int>
1 Adelie    Biscoe           43.2          19                 197        4775
2 Chinstrap Dream            52            20.7               210        4800
3 Gentoo    Biscoe           49.2          15.2               221        6300
# ‚Ñπ 2 more variables: sex <fct>, year <int>

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
Looking Closer
Let‚Äôs take this step-by-step

penguins |> group_by(species)

# A tibble: 344 √ó 8
# Groups:   species [3]
   species island    bill_length_mm bill_depth_mm flipper_length_mm body_mass_g
   <fct>   <fct>              <dbl>         <dbl>             <int>       <int>
 1 Adelie  Torgersen           39.1          18.7               181        3750
 2 Adelie  Torgersen           39.5          17.4               186        3800
 3 Adelie  Torgersen           40.3          18                 195        3250
 4 Adelie  Torgersen           NA            NA                  NA          NA
 5 Adelie  Torgersen           36.7          19.3               193        3450
 6 Adelie  Torgersen           39.3          20.6               190        3650
 7 Adelie  Torgersen           38.9          17.8               181        3625
 8 Adelie  Torgersen           39.2          19.6               195        4675
 9 Adelie  Torgersen           34.1          18.1               193        3475
10 Adelie  Torgersen           42            20.2               190        4250
# ‚Ñπ 334 more rows
# ‚Ñπ 2 more variables: sex <fct>, year <int>


Same data as before, but here # Groups: species[3]

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
Effects of group_by
group_by changes behavior of aggregating functions:

min(), max(), n(), sum(), prod(), etc.

Many other operations use these internally

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
Effects of group_by
Recall

penguins |> slice_max(body_mass_g)

is equivalent to:

penguins |> filter(body_mass_g == max(body_mass_g, na.rm=TRUE))

or even

penguins |> 
    mutate(mass_max = max(body_mass_g, na.rm=TRUE))
    filter(body_mass_g == mass_max)

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
Effects of group_by
Looking at the first step

penguins |> 
    mutate(mass_max = max(body_mass_g, na.rm=TRUE))



# A tibble: 344 √ó 3
  species body_mass_g mass_max
  <fct>         <int>    <int>
1 Adelie         3750     6300
2 Adelie         3800     6300
3 Adelie         3250     6300
# ‚Ñπ 341 more rows

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
Effects of group_by
With group_by, a different max for each group

penguins |> 
    group_by(species) |>
    mutate(mass_max = max(body_mass_g, na.rm=TRUE))



# A tibble: 344 √ó 3
# Groups:   species [3]
  species body_mass_g mass_max
  <fct>         <int>    <int>
1 Adelie         3750     4775
2 Adelie         3800     4775
3 Adelie         3250     4775
# ‚Ñπ 341 more rows

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
Effects of group_by
Hence,

penguins |> 
    group_by(species) |>
    mutate(mass_max = max(body_mass_g, na.rm=TRUE))
    filter(body_mass_g == mass_max)


penguins |> group_by(species) |> slice_max(body_mass_g)

# A tibble: 3 √ó 8
# Groups:   species [3]
  species   island bill_length_mm bill_depth_mm flipper_length_mm body_mass_g
  <fct>     <fct>           <dbl>         <dbl>             <int>       <int>
1 Adelie    Biscoe           43.2          19                 197        4775
2 Chinstrap Dream            52            20.7               210        4800
3 Gentoo    Biscoe           49.2          15.2               221        6300
# ‚Ñπ 2 more variables: sex <fct>, year <int>


gives a 3 row answer (one per group)

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
Compound Grouping
Can apply group_by to create ‚Äúcompound‚Äù groups

penguins |> group_by(species, year)

# A tibble: 344 √ó 8
# Groups:   species, year [9]
   species island    bill_length_mm bill_depth_mm flipper_length_mm body_mass_g
   <fct>   <fct>              <dbl>         <dbl>             <int>       <int>
 1 Adelie  Torgersen           39.1          18.7               181        3750
 2 Adelie  Torgersen           39.5          17.4               186        3800
 3 Adelie  Torgersen           40.3          18                 195        3250
 4 Adelie  Torgersen           NA            NA                  NA          NA
 5 Adelie  Torgersen           36.7          19.3               193        3450
 6 Adelie  Torgersen           39.3          20.6               190        3650
 7 Adelie  Torgersen           38.9          17.8               181        3625
 8 Adelie  Torgersen           39.2          19.6               195        4675
 9 Adelie  Torgersen           34.1          18.1               193        3475
10 Adelie  Torgersen           42            20.2               190        4250
# ‚Ñπ 334 more rows
# ‚Ñπ 2 more variables: sex <fct>, year <int>


\(9 = 3 \times 3\) groups

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
Compound Grouping
Grouped operations apply as before:

penguins |> 
    group_by(species, year) |> 
    slice_max(body_mass_g)

# Groups:   species, year [9]

  <fct>     <fct>              <dbl>         <dbl>             <int>       <int>
1 Adelie    Torgersen           39.2          19.6               195        4675
2 Adelie    Torgersen           42.9          17.6               196        4700
3 Adelie    Biscoe              43.2          19                 197        4775
4 Chinstrap Dream               49.2          18.2               195        4400
5 Chinstrap Dream               52            20.7               210        4800
6 Chinstrap Dream               50.8          18.5               201        4450
7 Gentoo    Biscoe              49.2          15.2               221        6300
8 Gentoo    Biscoe              51.1          16.3               220        6000
9 Gentoo    Biscoe              48.8          16.2               222        6000
# ‚Ñπ 2 more variables: sex <fct>, year <int>

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
Compound Grouping
Missing ‚Äòcombinations‚Äô automatically dropped:

penguins |> 
    group_by(species, island) 



# A tibble: 344 √ó 4
# Groups:   species, island [5]
   species island    body_mass_g sex   
   <fct>   <fct>           <int> <fct>

 2 Adelie  Torgersen        3800 female
 3 Adelie  Torgersen        3250 female

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
Grouping on Numeric Variables
In general, grouping on continuous variables is a bad choice:


# A tibble: 344 √ó 8
# Groups:   body_mass_g [95]
   species island    bill_length_mm bill_depth_mm flipper_length_mm body_mass_g
   <fct>   <fct>              <dbl>         <dbl>             <int>       <int>
 1 Adelie  Torgersen           39.1          18.7               181        3750
 2 Adelie  Torgersen           39.5          17.4               186        3800
 3 Adelie  Torgersen           40.3          18                 195        3250
 4 Adelie  Torgersen           NA            NA                  NA          NA
 5 Adelie  Torgersen           36.7          19.3               193        3450
 6 Adelie  Torgersen           39.3          20.6               190        3650
 7 Adelie  Torgersen           38.9          17.8               181        3625
 8 Adelie  Torgersen           39.2          19.6               195        4675
 9 Adelie  Torgersen           34.1          18.1               193        3475
10 Adelie  Torgersen           42            20.2               190        4250
# ‚Ñπ 334 more rows
# ‚Ñπ 2 more variables: sex <fct>, year <int>


(Analogy: Checking exact equality of continuous random variables)

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
Grouping on Numeric Variables
Better choices:

Group on quantiles (ntile) or cut points (cut)

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
rowwise Operations
Rarely, you may need to apply an operation to each row separately without vectorization
rowwise lets you do so - makes each row its own group

penguins |> rowwise()



# A tibble: 344 √ó 4
# Rowwise: 
  sex    island    flipper_length_mm body_mass_g
  <fct>  <fct>                 <int>       <int>
1 male   Torgersen               181        3750
2 female Torgersen               186        3800
# ‚Ñπ 342 more rows



Note: This is a bit dangerous - vectorization is important for data integrity

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
filter
While select is used for column selection, filter is used for row selection

penguins |> filter(bill_length_mm > 40)


Similar syntax to select:

No need to quote column names
Data is first (piped) argument
Later arguments specify action



Instead of names, provide logical tests (filters)

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
filter
Contrast

penguins |> filter(bill_length_mm > 40)

with

penguins[penguins$bill_length_mm > 40, ]

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
filter
Multiple filters give the intersection:

penguins |> filter(bill_length_mm > 40, sex == "female")


Use logical operators to get the union:

penguins |> filter(bill_length_mm > 40 | sex == "female")

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
filter
Pipes are very useful for multi-step operations

penguins |> filter(bill_length_mm > 40) |> select(species)


Compare to

select(filter(penguins, bill_length_mm > 40), species)

Piped form reads left to right instead of inside out

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
filter
Can use more complex comparisons in filter:

penguins |> filter(body_mass_g > mean(body_mass_g, na.rm=TRUE))

# A tibble: 149 √ó 8
   species island    bill_length_mm bill_depth_mm flipper_length_mm body_mass_g
   <fct>   <fct>              <dbl>         <dbl>             <int>       <int>
 1 Adelie  Torgersen           39.2          19.6               195        4675
 2 Adelie  Torgersen           42            20.2               190        4250
 3 Adelie  Torgersen           34.6          21.1               198        4400
 4 Adelie  Torgersen           42.5          20.7               197        4500
 5 Adelie  Dream               39.8          19.1               184        4650
 6 Adelie  Dream               44.1          19.7               196        4400
 7 Adelie  Dream               39.6          18.8               190        4600
 8 Adelie  Biscoe              40.1          18.9               188        4300
 9 Adelie  Biscoe              41.3          21.1               195        4400
10 Adelie  Torgersen           41.8          19.4               198        4450
# ‚Ñπ 139 more rows
# ‚Ñπ 2 more variables: sex <fct>, year <int>



What would happen without na.rm=TRUE? Why?

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
filter
Common mistake - using only a single equals sign for equality

penguins |> filter(sex = "female")

Error in `filter()`:
! We detected a named input.
‚Ñπ This usually means that you've used `=` instead of `==`.
‚Ñπ Did you mean `sex == "female"`?

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
slice functions
The slice_* family extend filter:

penguins |> slice_max(body_mass_g, n=1)

# A tibble: 1 √ó 8
  species island bill_length_mm bill_depth_mm flipper_length_mm body_mass_g
  <fct>   <fct>           <dbl>         <dbl>             <int>       <int>
1 Gentoo  Biscoe           49.2          15.2               221        6300
# ‚Ñπ 2 more variables: sex <fct>, year <int>



Equivalent to:

penguins |> filter(body_mass_g == max(body_mass_g, na.rm=TRUE))

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
slice functions
Standard slices:

slice_min
slice_max
slice_head
slice_tail


Specify one of:

n= to get top/bottom \(n\)
prop= to select a fraction

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
Data Frames in R
palmerpenguins


344 penguins observed on the Palmer Islands (Antarctica)
3 species, 3 islands, 3 years
4 numeric variables
One categorial (factor) variable (sex)

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
Data Frames in R
Key features:


Tabular (rows and columns) structure
Entries in the same column are all of the same type
Columns may be different types

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
Data Frames in R
Can be manipulated using standard R syntax:

table(penguins[penguins$bill_length_mm > 40, "species"])


   Adelie Chinstrap    Gentoo 
       51        68       123 




$ extracts a column as a vector
df[row index, column index]

Logical row indexing to select rows where bill_length_mm > 40
Column indexing by name to select a single column

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
What is Tidy Data?
‚ÄúTidy Data‚Äù:

Principles to make data manipulation safe and easy
Decrease chance of errors
Increase productivity


What does it mean to be tidy?


Everything in its proper place

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
Tidy Data
Recall our penguins:


  species bill_length_mm flipper_length_mm body_mass_g    sex
1  Adelie           39.1               181        3750   male
2  Adelie           39.5               186        3800 female
3  Adelie           40.3               195        3250 female
4  Adelie             NA                NA          NA   <NA>
5  Adelie           36.7               193        3450 female
6  Adelie           39.3               190        3650   male



Key features:


Each row is one observation (üêß)
Each column has one and only one fact
All values are in the table

Not hiding in row and column names

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
Tidy Data


Figure from R for Data Science by H. Wickham

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
Tidy - Why?
Why emphasize tidy data?

Minimize distractions:

Free to focus on analysis not code



Once data is ‚Äútidy‚Äù, you can focus on the real questions


First goal for data pre-processing (‚Äútidying up‚Äù)

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
Tidy - Who (and When)?
The name and principles of ‚Äútidy data‚Äù were popularized by H. Wickham (2014)

Core ideas are much older, dating back to (at least) Codd‚Äôs Relational Model in the 1970s, now ubiquitous in relational databases (SQL)


Now found in:

Python (pandas)
Julia (DataFrames)
Rust (polars)
and more

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
Tidy - How (and Where)?
tidyverse - Packages for Manipulating Tidy Data:


ggplot2: Visualization
dplyr: SQL-like operations
tidyr: Reshaping and cleaning data
readr: Ingest tidy data into R
Tidy manipulation of different data types:

stringr, forcats, lubridate




More helpers in the background (tibble, vctrs, ‚Ä¶)

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
Aside: tibbles
You will sometimes see tibble (tbl_df) as a synonym for data.frame

Minor differences in output formatting
Fewer edge cases

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
Some Untidy Examples
Baruch college business core enrollment:


# A tibble: 6 √ó 4
  Semester Course     Enrollment   Cap
  <chr>    <chr>           <dbl> <dbl>
1 Fall     Accounting        200   250
2 Fall     Law               100   125
3 Fall     Statistics        200   200
4 Spring   Accounting        300   350
5 Spring   Law                50   100
6 Spring   Statistics        400   400



Tidy! ‚úÖ



Each row is one unit (a class) üëç
Columns are well-typed üëç
One piece of information per column üëç

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
Some Untidy Examples


# A tibble: 6 √ó 3
  Semester Course     Enrollment  
  <chr>    <chr>      <chr>       
1 Fall     Accounting "200 of 250"
2 Fall     Law        "100 of 125"
3 Fall     Statistics "200 of 200"
4 Spring   Accounting "300 of 350"
5 Spring   Law        " 50 of 100"
6 Spring   Statistics "400 of 400"



Untidy! ‚ùå


Multiple pieces of information per cell (Enrollment)

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
Some Untidy Examples


# A tibble: 12 √ó 4
   Semester Course     Number Type      
   <chr>    <chr>       <dbl> <chr>

title: STA 9750 - OMSBA - Course Learning Objectives
text: This course provides an understanding of the principles and concepts of using computer tools for data analysis and visualization. Students will learn to use a scientific programming language (such as R) to import and export data from and into spreadsheets or other statistical software packages. They will gain experience in analyzing both quantitative and qualitative data, and statistical modelling techniques will be introduced. Written reports will prepare students for clear communication of their analysis in professional settings. This course is designed primarily for Masters‚Äô students in statistics and quantitative methods and modeling (QMM), and those interested in carrying out sophisticated statistical analyses of data using statistical software.

title: STA 9750 - OMSBA - Course Learning Objectives

Students will learn to use a scientific programming language (such as R) to import and export data from and into spreadsheets or other statistical software packages. They will gain experience in analyzing both quantitative and qualitative data, and statistical modelling techniques will be introduced. Written reports will prepare students for clear communication of their analysis in professional settings. This course is designed primarily for Masters‚Äô students in statistics and quantitative methods and modeling (QMM), and those interested in carrying out sophisticated statistical analyses of data using statistical software.

title: STA 9750 - OMSBA - Course Learning Objectives
text:
Program Learning Goals
This course contributes to the program learning goals of several MS programs offered by the Zicklin School of Business.

MS in Business Analytics
This course contributes to the following Program Learning Goals for the MS in Business Analytics:

MSBA Program Learning Goals







STA 9750 - OMSBA Learning Goal
MSBA Learning Goal
Description




‚úì
Data Management
Students will be able to apply methods, tools, and software for acquiring, managing/storing, and accessing structured and unstructured data. Students will also demonstrate knowledge of the strategic uses of data.


‚úì
Foundational Statistical / Quantitative Skills
Students will be able to prepare data for statistical analysis, perform basic exploratory and descriptive analysis as well as employ foundational statistical techniques needed to analyze data.


‚úì
Advanced Statistical/Quantitative Skills
Students will be able to build and interpret advanced predictive models. Students will be able to combine business rules and mathematical models to optimize business decisions from data.



Ethical Awareness
Students will be able to articulate an understanding of ethical issues in all phases of business analytics with particular emphasis on the new possibilities afforded by the emergence of big data.


‚úì
Professional Communication
Students will be able to explain complex analytical models and their results orally and in writing to technical and non technical/lay audiences.


‚úì
Knowledge Integration
Students will be able to apply the three key types of analytics (descriptive, predictive, and prescriptive) in a business domain to add value to business decision-making.





MS in Quantitative Methods & Modeling
This course contributes to the following Program Learning Goals for the MS in Quantitative Methods & Modeling:

MSQMM Program Learning Goals







STA 9750 - OMSBA Learning Goal
MSQMM Learning Goal
Description




‚úì
Operations Research & Mathematical Modeling
Students will be able to effectively model, evaluate, and solve quantitative (business) problems using quantitative modeling methods (e.g.¬†deterministic and probabilistic operations research techniques).


‚úì
Statistics
Students will be able to correctly apply appropriate statistical methods when defining, solving, and analyzing problems.


‚úì
Technology Competency
Students will be able to use current technological tools, including spreadsheets and specialized software, when solving problems.


‚úì
Professional Communication
Students will be able to effectively communicate their problem solving methods and solutions to technical and non-technical audiences.





MS in Statistics
This course contributes to the following Program Learning Goals for the MS in Statistics:

MS Statistics Program Learning Goals







STA 9750 - OMSBA Learning Goal
MS Stat Learning Goal
Description




‚úì
General Statistical Competence
Students will be able to apply appropriate probability models and statistical techniques when analyzing problems from business and other fields.


‚úì
Statistical Practice
Students will become familiar with the standard tools of statistical practice for multiple regression, along with the tools of a subset of specialized statistical areas such as multivariate analysis, applied sampling, time series analysis, experimental design, data mining, categorical analysis, and/or stochastic processes.


‚úì
Technology Competency
Students will learn to use one or more of the benchmark statistical software platforms, such as SAS or R.

Tidy Data
Recall our definition of ‚Äútidy‚Äù data - everything in its proper place:


One and only one type of information per column
One and only one observation per row
No values ‚Äòhiding‚Äô in column or row names



Return of the palmerpenguins:

  <fct>   <fct>              <dbl>

Make sure to load the tidyverse package before using

‚úî dplyr     1.1.4     ‚úî readr     2.1.5
‚úî forcats   1.0.0     ‚úî stringr   1.5.1
‚úî ggplot2   3.5.2     ‚úî tibble    3.2.1
‚úî lubridate 1.9.4     ‚úî tidyr     1.3.1
‚úî purrr     1.0.4     
‚îÄ‚îÄ Conflicts ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ tidyverse_conflicts() ‚îÄ‚îÄ

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
dplyr
You have already seen one tidyverse package: ggplot2

Today we start with dplyr - ‚Äògrammar of data manipulation‚Äô

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
select
The select function can be used to select certain columns

select(penguins, species, bill_length_mm, body_mass_g, sex)

# A tibble: 344 √ó 4
   species bill_length_mm body_mass_g sex   
   <fct>            <dbl>       <int> <fct> 
 1 Adelie            39.1        3750 male  
 2 Adelie            39.5        3800 female
 3 Adelie            40.3        3250 female
 4 Adelie            NA            NA <NA>  
 5 Adelie            36.7        3450 female
 6 Adelie            39.3        3650 male  
 7 Adelie            38.9        3625 female
 8 Adelie            39.2        4675 male  
 9 Adelie            34.1        3475 <NA>  
10 Adelie            42          4250 <NA>  
# ‚Ñπ 334 more rows



Arguments: data => columns we want

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
select
Contrast

select(penguins, species, bill_length_mm, body_mass_g, sex)

with

penguins[,c("species", "bill_length_mm", "body_mass_g", "sex")]



Key differences:

No quotes around column names
Pass names as arguments, not 1 vector

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
Put that in your Pipe
R supports piped operations - feeding the output of one function into another

select(penguins, species, bill_length_mm, body_mass_g, sex)

is equivalent to

penguins |> select(species, bill_length_mm, body_mass_g, sex)


Read |> as ‚Äúand then‚Äù
dplyr plays very nicely with pipes

penguins |> select(-species)

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
Goals for this Video
In this video:


mutate rows to safely transform data
Perform conditional transformations
Compute running and cumulative statistics
Apply simple aggregation and window functions

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
mutate
So far we have only subsetted our data. Can we create new columns?


penguins |> 
    mutate(body_mass_lb = body_mass_g / 453) |>
    select(contains("body"))

# A tibble: 344 √ó 2
   body_mass_g body_mass_lb
         <int>        <dbl>
 1        3750         8.28
 2        3800         8.39
 3        3250         7.17
 4          NA        NA   
 5        3450         7.62
 6        3650         8.06
 7        3625         8.00
 8        4675        10.3 
 9        3475         7.67
10        4250         9.38
# ‚Ñπ 334 more rows

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
mutate

penguins |> 
    mutate(body_mass_lb = body_mass_g / 453) |>
    select(contains("body"))

Similar syntax to select and filter

Put name on the left of the =
If you omit a name, unhelpful default:

penguins |> mutate(body_mass_g / 453) |> select(contains("body"))



# A tibble: 344 √ó 2
  body_mass_g `body_mass_g/453`
        <int>             <dbl>
1        3750              8.28
2        3800              8.39
3        3250              7.17
# ‚Ñπ 341 more rows

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
mutate
Can do arbitrary vectorized operations and access recently created columns:

penguins |> 
    select(where(is.numeric)) |>
    mutate(weight_kg = body_mass_g / 1000,
           height_m = body_height_mm / 1000, 
           bmi = weight_kg / height_m^2)

(Sadly, don‚Äôt actually have height data)

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
mutate helpers
?mutate lists several helpful functions:

if_else, case_when
cumsum, cummean
lead, lag
min_rank, dense_rank

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
Complex Transforms
Use case_when for transforms that depend on other values:

penguins |>
  mutate(cuteness_level = 
    case_when(
        species == "Adelie" ~ "Exceptionally", 
        species == "Gentoo" ~ "Remarkably",
        species == "Chinstrap" ~ "Stunningly"
    )) |>
  select(species, cuteness_level, body_mass_g) |> 
  slice_head(n=5)

# A tibble: 5 √ó 3
  species cuteness_level body_mass_g
  <fct>   <chr>                <int>
1 Adelie  Exceptionally         3750
2 Adelie  Exceptionally         3800
3 Adelie  Exceptionally         3250
4 Adelie  Exceptionally           NA
5 Adelie  Exceptionally         3450

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
Complex Transforms
case_when specifies a series of tests. First one passed is used:

case_when(
    test1 ~ value1, 
    test2 ~ value2
    ...
)

Use TRUE for default values

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
Cumulative Stats
The cum* family of functions compute cumulative values

cummean
cummax, cummin
cumsum, cumprod


These depend on the order of the data
You may want to use arrange to order data first

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
Cumulative Stats

penguins |>
    arrange(body_mass_g) |> # Defaults to increasing; use desc() to reverse
    mutate(average_mass = cummean(body_mass_g), 
           number_of_penguins = row_number()) |>
    select(species, 
           body_mass_g,
           average_mass,  
           number_of_penguins) |>
    slice_head(n=5)

# A tibble: 5 √ó 4
  species   body_mass_g average_mass number_of_penguins
  <fct>           <int>        <dbl>              <int>
1 Chinstrap        2700         2700                  1
2 Adelie           2850         2775                  2
3 Adelie           2850         2800                  3
4 Adelie           2900         2825                  4
5 Adelie           2900         2840                  5


Rolling statistics are a bit trickier - look into RcppRoll

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
Ranking
To assign ranks, use the *_rank functions:

penguins |>
    mutate(body_mass_rank = min_rank(body_mass_g)) |>
    select(contains("body_mass")) |>
    slice_head(n=5)

# A tibble: 5 √ó 2
  body_mass_g body_mass_rank
        <int>          <int>
1        3750            121
2        3800            130
3        3250             29
4          NA             NA
5        3450             61



min_rank and dense_rank differ in treatment of ties

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
Ranking
percent_rank and cume_dist for CDF-type ranking

penguins |>
    mutate(body_mass_pct_rank = round(percent_rank(body_mass_g), 2),
           body_mass_cdf      = round(cume_dist(body_mass_g), 2)) |>
    select(contains("body_mass")) |>
    slice_head(n=5)

# A tibble: 5 √ó 3
  body_mass_g body_mass_pct_rank body_mass_cdf
        <int>              <dbl>         <dbl>
1        3750               0.35          0.37
2        3800               0.38          0.41
3        3250               0.08          0.1 
4          NA              NA            NA   
5        3450               0.18          0.2 


CDF: cume_dist \(\leq\) vs percent_rank \(<\)

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
Ranking
Use ntile to split data into quartiles, deciles, etc.

penguins |>
    mutate(body_mass_decile = ntile(body_mass_g, 10)) |>
    select(contains("body_mass")) |>
    slice_head(n=5)

# A tibble: 5 √ó 2
  body_mass_g body_mass_decile
        <int>            <int>
1        3750                4
2        3800                4
3        3250                1
4          NA               NA
5        3450                2

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
In this video:


Combine multiple rows using summarize
Compute overall and group-wise summary statistics

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
You have already seen group_by modify the operation of ‚Äòaggregation‚Äô functions:

min, max
mean, sum,
ntile

etc
. . .
No reduction in data complexity unless combined with filter

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
group_by and summarize \(\implies\) summary statistics

penguins |> 
    group_by(species) |> 
    summarize(avg_mass = mean(body_mass_g, na.rm=TRUE))

# A tibble: 3 √ó 2
  species   avg_mass
  <fct>        <dbl>
1 Adelie       3701.
2 Chinstrap    3733.
3 Gentoo       5076.


. . .
Unlike filter, these are new rows:

One row summarizing each group
Not a subset of old rows

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
penguins |> 
    group_by(species) |> 
    summarize(avg_mass = mean(body_mass_g, na.rm=TRUE))

# A tibble: 3 √ó 2
  species   avg_mass
  <fct>        <dbl>
1 Adelie       3701.
2 Chinstrap    3733.
3 Gentoo       5076.


What happened to other features (e.g., flipper_length_mm)?
. . .
summarize only keeps:

Grouping variables (species)
Created variables (avg_mass)

All other data is dropped

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
Can perform multiple summaries at once:

penguins |> 
    group_by(species) |> 
    summarize(avg_mass = mean(body_mass_g, na.rm=TRUE), 
              sd_mass = sd(body_mass_g, na.rm=TRUE))

# A tibble: 3 √ó 3
  species   avg_mass sd_mass
  <fct>        <dbl>   <dbl>
1 Adelie       3701.    459.
2 Chinstrap    3733.    384.
3 Gentoo       5076.    504.


Important to do all summaries in one call

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
The n() function will count the number of rows in a group

penguins |> 
    group_by(species) |> 
    summarize(mass_avg = mean(body_mass_g, na.rm=TRUE), 
              mass_sd = sd(body_mass_g, na.rm=TRUE), 
              n = n(), 
              mass_se = mass_sd / sqrt(n))

# A tibble: 3 √ó 5
  species   mass_avg mass_sd     n mass_se
  <fct>        <dbl>   <dbl> <int>   <dbl>
1 Adelie       3701.    459.   152    37.2
2 Chinstrap    3733.    384.    68    46.6
3 Gentoo       5076.    504.   124    45.3

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
cur_group() returns the current group name

penguins |> 
    group_by(species) |> 
    summarize(mass_avg = mean(body_mass_g, na.rm=TRUE), 
              mass_sd = sd(body_mass_g, na.rm=TRUE), 
              n = n(), 
              mass_se = mass_sd / sqrt(n), 
              species_cap = toupper(cur_group()))

# A tibble: 3 √ó 6
  species   mass_avg mass_sd     n mass_se species_cap
  <fct>        <dbl>   <dbl> <int>   <dbl> <chr>      
1 Adelie       3701.    459.   152    37.2 1          
2 Chinstrap    3733.    384.    68    46.6 2          
3 Gentoo       5076.    504.   124    45.3 3          


Can also use species directly

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
summarize removes grouping
summarize removes the last level of grouping

penguins |> 
    group_by(species) |> 
    summarize(mass_avg = mean(body_mass_g, na.rm=TRUE))

# A tibble: 3 √ó 2
  species   mass_avg
  <fct>        <dbl>
1 Adelie       3701.
2 Chinstrap    3733.
3 Gentoo       5076.


No grouping remains

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
summarize removes grouping
summarize removes the last level of grouping

penguins |> 
    group_by(species, sex) |> 
    summarize(mass_avg = mean(body_mass_g, na.rm=TRUE))

`summarise()` has grouped output by 'species'. You can override using the
`.groups` argument.


# A tibble: 8 √ó 3
# Groups:   species [3]
  species   sex    mass_avg
  <fct>     <fct>     <dbl>
1 Adelie    female    3369.
2 Adelie    male      4043.
3 Adelie    <NA>      3540 
4 Chinstrap female    3527.
5 Chinstrap male      3939.
6 Gentoo    female    4680.
7 Gentoo    male      5485.
8 Gentoo    <NA>      4588.


Grouping by species still active

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
summarize removes grouping
Advice:

group_by should be as close to summarize as possible
ungroup and re-group_by defensively

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
summarize column names
Like mutate, you should always give summarize column names
Defaults are unhelpful:

penguins |> 
    group_by(species) |>
    summarize(sd(body_mass_g, na.rm=TRUE))

# A tibble: 3 √ó 2
  species   `sd(body_mass_g, na.rm = TRUE)`
  <fct>                               <dbl>
1 Adelie                               459.
2 Chinstrap                            384.
3 Gentoo                               504.

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
summarize multiple columns
Remember the selection helpers from select

penguins |> 
    select(where(is.numeric))

# A tibble: 344 √ó 5
   bill_length_mm bill_depth_mm flipper_length_mm body_mass_g  year
            <dbl>         <dbl>             <int>       <int> <int>
 1           39.1          18.7               181        3750  2007
 2           39.5          17.4               186        3800  2007
 3           40.3          18                 195        3250  2007
 4           NA            NA                  NA          NA  2007
 5           36.7          19.3               193        3450  2007
 6           39.3          20.6               190        3650  2007
 7           38.9          17.8               181        3625  2007
 8           39.2          19.6               195        4675  2007
 9           34.1          18.1               193        3475  2007
10           42            20.2               190        4250  2007
# ‚Ñπ 334 more rows

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
summarize multiple columns
Can be used inside summarize as well

safe_mean <- function(x) mean(x, na.rm=TRUE)
penguins |> 
    group_by(species) |>
    summarize(across(where(is.numeric), safe_mean))

# A tibble: 3 √ó 6
  species   bill_length_mm bill_depth_mm flipper_length_mm body_mass_g  year
  <fct>              <dbl>         <dbl>             <dbl>       <dbl> <dbl>
1 Adelie              38.8          18.3              190.       3701. 2008.
2 Chinstrap           48.8          18.4              196.       3733. 2008.
3 Gentoo              47.5          15.0              217.       5076. 2008.

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
summarize without group_by
Without group_by, summarize takes summaries of the entire data set:

penguins |> 
    summarize(n=n(), 
              across(where(is.numeric), safe_mean))

# A tibble: 1 √ó 6
      n bill_length_mm bill_depth_mm flipper_length_mm body_mass_g  year
  <dbl>          <dbl>         <dbl>             <dbl>       <dbl> <dbl>
1   344           43.9          17.2              201.       4202. 2008.

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
summarize computes summary statistics of a population

means, standard deviations, counts, etc.

group_by changes these to conditional summary statistics

E.g., mean of body mass, conditional on adelie species

. . .
Many steps of real data analysis fits this pattern
If you dive deeper into split-apply-combine, can determine group-wise models as well (e.g., different trends for different groups)

Often in data analysis, we combine data from multiple sources to create new insights
joins provide us a unified framework for combining data sets

In R, we specify joins with the join_by function

inner_join(band_instruments, band_members, join_by(name == name))

join_by gives a ‚ÄúJoin Specification‚Äù

name == name are column names from first and second table
Be explicit or R will ‚Äúauto-guess‚Äù based on names matched




inner_join discards unmatched rows


inner_join(band_instruments, 
           band_members, 
           join_by(name == name))

# A tibble: 2 √ó 3
  name  plays  band   
  <chr> <chr>  <chr>  
1 John  guitar Beatles
2 Paul  bass   Beatles





full_join keeps all rows


full_join(band_instruments, 
          band_members, 
          join_by(name == name))

# A tibble: 4 √ó 3
  name  plays  band   
  <chr> <chr>  <chr>  
1 John  guitar Beatles
2 Paul  bass   Beatles
3 Keith guitar <NA>   
4 Mick  <NA>   Stones 





left_join keeps unmatched rows from first table


left_join(band_instruments, 
          band_members, 
          join_by(name == name))

# A tibble: 3 √ó 3
  name  plays  band   
  <chr> <chr>  <chr>  
1 John  guitar Beatles
2 Paul  bass   Beatles
3 Keith guitar <NA>

right_join(band_instruments, 
           band_members, 
           join_by(name == name))

# A tibble: 3 √ó 3
  name  plays  band   
  <chr> <chr>  <chr>  
1 John  guitar Beatles
2 Paul  bass   Beatles
3 Mick  <NA>   Stones 





Type of join depends on treatment of missing values

Why is data missing?
If going to na.rm=TRUE, inner_join
If going to investigate further, full or left/right

Let‚Äôs compute the z-scores of mass for our penguins by species

penguin_stats <- penguins |>
    group_by(species) |>
    summarize(mass_mean = mean(body_mass_g, na.rm=TRUE), 
              mass_sd = sd(body_mass_g, na.rm=TRUE))

               join_by(species == species)) |>

    inner_join(penguin_stats, 
               join_by(species == species)) |>
    mutate(mass_z = (body_mass_g - mass_mean) / mass_sd) |>
    select(species, body_mass_g, mass_z)

Tidy Data Manipulation

Selecting Rows and Columns
Computing Groupwise Summaries
Joining Tables
Reshaping Tables

python Basics
Web Scraping with python





In this video:


Combine multiple rows using summarize
Compute overall and group-wise summary statistics





You have already seen group_by modify the operation of ‚Äòaggregation‚Äô functions:

min, max
mean, sum,
ntile

etc
. . .
No reduction in data complexity unless combined with filter



group_by and summarize \(\implies\) summary statistics

penguins |> 
    group_by(species) |> 
    summarize(avg_mass = mean(body_mass_g, na.rm=TRUE))

# A tibble: 3 √ó 2
  species   avg_mass
  <fct>        <dbl>
1 Adelie       3701.
2 Chinstrap    3733.
3 Gentoo       5076.


. . .
Unlike filter, these are new rows:

One row summarizing each group
Not a subset of old rows





penguins |> 
    group_by(species) |> 
    summarize(avg_mass = mean(body_mass_g, na.rm=TRUE))

# A tibble: 3 √ó 2
  species   avg_mass
  <fct>        <dbl>
1 Adelie       3701.
2 Chinstrap    3733.
3 Gentoo       5076.


What happened to other features (e.g., flipper_length_mm)?
. . .
summarize only keeps:

Grouping variables (species)
Created variables (avg_mass)

All other data is dropped



Can perform multiple summaries at once:

penguins |> 
    group_by(species) |> 
    summarize(avg_mass = mean(body_mass_g, na.rm=TRUE), 
              sd_mass = sd(body_mass_g, na.rm=TRUE))

# A tibble: 3 √ó 3
  species   avg_mass sd_mass
  <fct>        <dbl>   <dbl>
1 Adelie       3701.    459.
2 Chinstrap    3733.    384.
3 Gentoo       5076.    504.


Important to do all summaries in one call



The n() function will count the number of rows in a group

penguins |> 
    group_by(species) |> 
    summarize(mass_avg = mean(body_mass_g, na.rm=TRUE), 
              mass_sd = sd(body_mass_g, na.rm=TRUE), 
              n = n(), 
              mass_se = mass_sd / sqrt(n))

# A tibble: 3 √ó 5
  species   mass_avg mass_sd     n mass_se
  <fct>        <dbl>   <dbl> <int>   <dbl>
1 Adelie       3701.    459.   152    37.2
2 Chinstrap    3733.    384.    68    46.6
3 Gentoo       5076.    504.   124    45.3





cur_group() returns the current group name

penguins |> 
    group_by(species) |> 
    summarize(mass_avg = mean(body_mass_g, na.rm=TRUE), 
              mass_sd = sd(body_mass_g, na.rm=TRUE), 
              n = n(), 
              mass_se = mass_sd / sqrt(n), 
              species_cap = toupper(cur_group()))

# A tibble: 3 √ó 6
  species   mass_avg mass_sd     n mass_se species_cap
  <fct>        <dbl>   <dbl> <int>   <dbl> <chr>      
1 Adelie       3701.    459.   152    37.2 1          
2 Chinstrap    3733.    384.    68    46.6 2          
3 Gentoo       5076.    504.   124    45.3 3          


Can also use species directly



summarize removes the last level of grouping

penguins |> 
    group_by(species) |> 
    summarize(mass_avg = mean(body_mass_g, na.rm=TRUE))

# A tibble: 3 √ó 2
  species   mass_avg
  <fct>        <dbl>
1 Adelie       3701.
2 Chinstrap    3733.
3 Gentoo       5076.


No grouping remains



summarize removes the last level of grouping

penguins |> 
    group_by(species, sex) |> 
    summarize(mass_avg = mean(body_mass_g, na.rm=TRUE))



`summarise()` has grouped output by 'species'. You can override using the
`.groups` argument.


# A tibble: 8 √ó 3
# Groups:   species [3]
  species   sex    mass_avg
  <fct>     <fct>     <dbl>
1 Adelie    female    3369.
2 Adelie    male      4043.
3 Adelie    <NA>      3540 
4 Chinstrap female    3527.
5 Chinstrap male      3939.
# ‚Ñπ 3 more rows


Grouping by species still active



Advice:

group_by should be as close to summarize as possible
ungroup and re-group_by defensively




Like mutate, give summarize column names
Defaults are unhelpful:

penguins |> 
    group_by(species) |>
    summarize(sd(body_mass_g, na.rm=TRUE))

# A tibble: 3 √ó 2
  species   `sd(body_mass_g, na.rm = TRUE)`
  <fct>                               <dbl>
1 Adelie                               459.
2 Chinstrap                            384.
3 Gentoo                               504.





Remember the selection helpers from select

penguins |> 
    select(where(is.numeric)) |>
    print(n=4)

# A tibble: 344 √ó 5
  bill_length_mm bill_depth_mm flipper_length_mm body_mass_g  year
           <dbl>         <dbl>             <int>       <int> <int>
1           39.1          18.7               181        3750  2007
2           39.5          17.4               186        3800  2007
3           40.3          18                 195        3250  2007
4           NA            NA                  NA          NA  2007
# ‚Ñπ 340 more rows





Can be used inside summarize as well

safe_mean <- function(x) mean(x, na.rm=TRUE)
penguins |> 
    group_by(species) |>
    summarize(across(where(is.numeric), safe_mean))

# A tibble: 3 √ó 6
  species   bill_length_mm bill_depth_mm flipper_length_mm body_mass_g  year
  <fct>              <dbl>         <dbl>             <dbl>       <dbl> <dbl>
1 Adelie              38.8          18.3              190.       3701. 2008.
2 Chinstrap           48.8          18.4              196.       3733. 2008.
3 Gentoo              47.5          15.0              217.       5076. 2008.





Without group_by, summarize takes summaries of the entire data set:

penguins |> 
    summarize(n=n(), 
              across(where(is.numeric), safe_mean))

# A tibble: 1 √ó 6
      n bill_length_mm bill_depth_mm flipper_length_mm body_mass_g  year
  <dbl>          <dbl>         <dbl>             <dbl>       <dbl> <dbl>
1   344           43.9          17.2              201.       4202. 2008.





summarize computes summary statistics of a population

means, standard deviations, counts, etc.

group_by changes these to conditional summary statistics

E.g., mean of body mass, conditional on adelie species

. . .
Many steps of real data analysis fits this pattern
If you dive deeper into split-apply-combine, can determine group-wise models as well (e.g., different trends for different groups)

Summarize Across Multiple Rows ‚úÖ

Reshape Tables with pivot Operations




For more, check out Sections 3.5-3.6 - ‚ÄúGroups‚Äù of R for Data Science

In this video:


Identify wide and long format data
Pivot data from wide to long format
Pivot data from long to wide format





Recall our Baruch enrollment example of tidy data ‚úÖ


# A tibble: 6 √ó 4
  Semester Course     Enrollment   Cap
  <chr>    <chr>           <dbl> <dbl>
1 Fall     Accounting        200   250
2 Fall     Law               100   125
3 Fall     Statistics        200   200
4 Spring   Accounting        300   350
5 Spring   Law                50   100
6 Spring   Statistics        400   400





We can plot this

ggplot(D, aes(x=Semester, y=Enrollment, color=Course)) +
    geom_jitter() + theme_bw()











Not easy to plot both Enrollment and Cap columns
. . .
Need data in this ‚Äúuntidy‚Äù format


# A tibble: 12 √ó 4
   Semester Course     Number Type      
   <chr>    <chr>       <dbl> <chr>     
 1 Fall     Accounting    200 Enrollment
 2 Fall     Accounting    250 Cap       
 3 Fall     Law           100 Enrollment
 4 Fall     Law           125 Cap       
 5 Fall     Statistics    200 Enrollment
 6 Fall     Statistics    200 Cap       
 7 Spring   Accounting    300 Enrollment
 8 Spring   Accounting    350 Cap       
 9 Spring   Law            50 Enrollment
10 Spring   Law           100 Cap       
11 Spring   Statistics    400 Enrollment
12 Spring   Statistics    400 Cap       






ggplot(D2, aes(x=Semester, y=Number, shape=Type, color=Course)) +
    geom_jitter() + theme_bw() + theme(legend.position = "bottom")











We switched from a ‚Äúwide‚Äù format to a ‚Äúlong‚Äù format

Not absolute terms, relative to each other
Wide has more columns (tidier)
Long is easier for certain plots




pivot operations can be used to switch between formats

pivot_longer combine columns
pivot_wider split a column

Syntax is hard to remember - use ?pivot_wider and ?pivot_longer for examples




pivot_longer(D, 
             cols=c(Enrollment, Cap), 
             names_to="Type",  # Quote since not a current column
             values_to="Number")



# A tibble: 12 √ó 4
  Semester Course     Type       Number
  <chr>    <chr>      <chr>       <dbl>
1 Fall     Accounting Enrollment    200
2 Fall     Accounting Cap           250
3 Fall     Law        Enrollment    100
# ‚Ñπ 9 more rows



cols to pivot
names_to: column where to put (old) column name
values_to: column where to store old values





pivot_wider(D2, 
            id_cols = c(Semester, Course), 
            values_from = Number, 
            names_from = Type)

# A tibble: 6 √ó 4
  Semester Course     Enrollment   Cap
  <chr>    <chr>           <dbl> <dbl>
1 Fall     Accounting        200   250
2 Fall     Law               100   125
3 Fall     Statistics        200   200
4 Spring   Accounting        300   350
5 Spring   Law                50   100
6 Spring   Statistics        400   400



id_cols: columns kept in place
names_from: column where to get new column names
values_from: column where to get values

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
R Basics
Data Visualization
R Programming
Tidy Data Manipulation

Selecting Rows and Columns
Computing Groupwise Summaries
Joining Tables
Reshaping Tables

python Basics
Web Scraping with python





In this video:


Understand ‚Äúgrouped‚Äù dplyr operations
Use nested/compound group structures
Apply rowwise() operations





So far, we have applied vectorized operations to data.frames:

select: Keep and drop columns
mutate: Create new columns
filter: Keep and drop rows

. . .
For each of these, we have operated on the whole data set
Often, we instead want to operate on chunks of the data at a time



Recall our penguins:

penguins



# A tibble: 344 √ó 3
  species bill_length_mm body_mass_g
  <fct>            <dbl>       <int>
1 Adelie            39.1        3750
2 Adelie            39.5        3800
3 Adelie            40.3        3250
# ‚Ñπ 341 more rows


. . .
Heaviest penguin:

penguins |> slice_max(body_mass_g)



# A tibble: 1 √ó 3
  species bill_length_mm body_mass_g
  <fct>            <dbl>       <int>
1 Gentoo            49.2        6300





How can we get the heaviest penguin of each species?
. . .
Conceptually:

Split the data into three groups
Apply slice_max to each group separately
Combine the three rows back together

. . .
Sometimes called the split-apply-combine paradigm



Implemented using the group_by adverb

Doesn‚Äôt do anything on its own
Changes the behavior of other functions

. . .

penguins |> group_by(species) |> slice_max(body_mass_g)

# A tibble: 3 √ó 8
# Groups:   species [3]
  species   island bill_length_mm bill_depth_mm flipper_length_mm body_mass_g
  <fct>     <fct>           <dbl>         <dbl>             <int>       <int>
1 Adelie    Biscoe           43.2          19                 197        4775
2 Chinstrap Dream            52            20.7               210        4800
3 Gentoo    Biscoe           49.2          15.2               221        6300
# ‚Ñπ 2 more variables: sex <fct>, year <int>





Let‚Äôs take this step-by-step

penguins |> group_by(species)

# A tibble: 344 √ó 8
# Groups:   species [3]
   species island    bill_length_mm bill_depth_mm flipper_length_mm body_mass_g
   <fct>   <fct>              <dbl>         <dbl>             <int>       <int>
 1 Adelie  Torgersen           39.1          18.7               181        3750
 2 Adelie  Torgersen           39.5          17.4               186        3800
 3 Adelie  Torgersen           40.3          18                 195        3250
 4 Adelie  Torgersen           NA            NA                  NA          NA
 5 Adelie  Torgersen           36.7          19.3               193        3450
 6 Adelie  Torgersen           39.3          20.6               190        3650
 7 Adelie  Torgersen           38.9          17.8               181        3625
 8 Adelie  Torgersen           39.2          19.6               195        4675
 9 Adelie  Torgersen           34.1          18.1               193        3475
10 Adelie  Torgersen           42            20.2               190        4250
# ‚Ñπ 334 more rows
# ‚Ñπ 2 more variables: sex <fct>, year <int>


Same data as before, but here # Groups: species[3]



group_by changes behavior of aggregating functions:

min(), max(), n(), sum(), prod(), etc.

Many other operations use these internally



Recall

penguins |> slice_max(body_mass_g)

is equivalent to:

penguins |> filter(body_mass_g == max(body_mass_g, na.rm=TRUE))

or even

penguins |> 
    mutate(mass_max = max(body_mass_g, na.rm=TRUE))
    filter(body_mass_g == mass_max)




Looking at the first step

penguins |> 
    mutate(mass_max = max(body_mass_g, na.rm=TRUE))



# A tibble: 344 √ó 3
  species body_mass_g mass_max
  <fct>         <int>    <int>
1 Adelie         3750     6300
2 Adelie         3800     6300
3 Adelie         3250     6300
# ‚Ñπ 341 more rows





With group_by, a different max for each group

penguins |> 
    group_by(species) |>
    mutate(mass_max = max(body_mass_g, na.rm=TRUE))



# A tibble: 344 √ó 3
# Groups:   species [3]
  species body_mass_g mass_max
  <fct>         <int>    <int>
1 Adelie         3750     4775
2 Adelie         3800     4775
3 Adelie         3250     4775
# ‚Ñπ 341 more rows





Hence,

penguins |> 
    group_by(species) |>
    mutate(mass_max = max(body_mass_g, na.rm=TRUE))
    filter(body_mass_g == mass_max)


penguins |> group_by(species) |> slice_max(body_mass_g)

# A tibble: 3 √ó 8
# Groups:   species [3]
  species   island bill_length_mm bill_depth_mm flipper_length_mm body_mass_g
  <fct>     <fct>           <dbl>         <dbl>             <int>       <int>
1 Adelie    Biscoe           43.2          19                 197        4775
2 Chinstrap Dream            52            20.7               210        4800
3 Gentoo    Biscoe           49.2          15.2               221        6300
# ‚Ñπ 2 more variables: sex <fct>, year <int>


gives a 3 row answer (one per group)



Operations do not have to select only a single row like slice_max
. . .
To get ‚Äúabove average‚Äù penguins for each species

penguins |> 
    group_by(species) |> 
    filter(body_mass_g > mean(body_mass_g, na.rm=TRUE))




Can apply group_by to create ‚Äúcompound‚Äù groups

penguins |> group_by(species, year)

# A tibble: 344 √ó 8
# Groups:   species, year [9]
   species island    bill_length_mm bill_depth_mm flipper_length_mm body_mass_g

\(9 = 3 \times 3\) groups



Grouped operations apply as before:

penguins |> 
    group_by(species, year) |> 
    slice_max(body_mass_g)

# A tibble: 9 √ó 8
# Groups:   species, year [9]
  species   island    bill_length_mm bill_depth_mm flipper_length_mm body_mass_g
  <fct>     <fct>              <dbl>         <dbl>             <int>       <int>
1 Adelie    Torgersen           39.2          19.6               195        4675
2 Adelie    Torgersen           42.9          17.6               196        4700
3 Adelie    Biscoe              43.2          19                 197        4775
4 Chinstrap Dream               49.2          18.2               195        4400
5 Chinstrap Dream               52            20.7               210        4800
6 Chinstrap Dream               50.8          18.5               201        4450
7 Gentoo    Biscoe              49.2          15.2               221        6300
8 Gentoo    Biscoe              51.1          16.3               220        6000
9 Gentoo    Biscoe              48.8          16.2               222        6000
# ‚Ñπ 2 more variables: sex <fct>, year <int>





Missing ‚Äòcombinations‚Äô automatically dropped:

penguins |> 
    group_by(species, island) 



# A tibble: 344 √ó 4
# Groups:   species, island [5]
   species island    body_mass_g sex   
   <fct>   <fct>           <int> <fct> 
 1 Adelie  Torgersen        3750 male  
 2 Adelie  Torgersen        3800 female
 3 Adelie  Torgersen        3250 female
 4 Adelie  Torgersen          NA <NA>  
 5 Adelie  Torgersen        3450 female
 6 Adelie  Torgersen        3650 male  
 7 Adelie  Torgersen        3625 female
 8 Adelie  Torgersen        4675 male  
 9 Adelie  Torgersen        3475 <NA>  
10 Adelie  Torgersen        4250 <NA>  
# ‚Ñπ 334 more rows





Once you are done with grouped operations, ungroup

penguins |> 
    group_by(species, island) |>
    slice_max(body_mass_g) |>
    ungroup()

# A tibble: 5 √ó 8
  species   island    bill_length_mm bill_depth_mm flipper_length_mm body_mass_g
  <fct>     <fct>              <dbl>         <dbl>             <int>       <int>
1 Adelie    Biscoe              43.2          19                 197        4775
2 Adelie    Dream               39.8          19.1               184        4650
3 Adelie    Torgersen           42.9          17.6               196        4700
4 Chinstrap Dream               52            20.7               210        4800
5 Gentoo    Biscoe              49.2          15.2               221        6300
# ‚Ñπ 2 more variables: sex <fct>, year <int>





In general, grouping on continuous variables is a bad choice:

penguins |> group_by(body_mass_g)

# A tibble: 344 √ó 8
# Groups:   body_mass_g [95]
   species island    bill_length_mm bill_depth_mm flipper_length_mm body_mass_g
   <fct>   <fct>              <dbl>         <dbl>             <int>       <int>
 1 Adelie  Torgersen           39.1          18.7               181        3750
 2 Adelie  Torgersen           39.5          17.4               186        3800
 3 Adelie  Torgersen           40.3          18                 195        3250
 4 Adelie  Torgersen           NA            NA                  NA          NA
 5 Adelie  Torgersen           36.7          19.3               193        3450
 6 Adelie  Torgersen           39.3          20.6               190        3650
 7 Adelie  Torgersen           38.9          17.8               181        3625
 8 Adelie  Torgersen           39.2          19.6               195        4675
 9 Adelie  Torgersen           34.1          18.1               193        3475
10 Adelie  Torgersen           42            20.2               190        4250
# ‚Ñπ 334 more rows
# ‚Ñπ 2 more variables: sex <fct>, year <int>


(Analogy: Checking exact equality of continuous random variables)



Better choices:

Group on quantiles (ntile) or cut points (cut)


penguins |>
    mutate(mass_5ile = ntile(body_mass_g, 5)) |>
    group_by(mass_5ile) |>
    ...




Rarely, you may need to apply an operation to each row separately without vectorization
rowwise lets you do so - makes each row its own group

penguins |> rowwise()



# A tibble: 344 √ó 4
# Rowwise: 
  sex    island    flipper_length_mm body_mass_g
  <fct>  <fct>                 <int>       <int>
1 male   Torgersen               181        3750
2 female Torgersen               186        3800
# ‚Ñπ 342 more rows


. . .
Note: This is a bit dangerous - vectorization is important for data integrity
